Deer are SO skiddish. You’ve heard the phrase, “you look like a deer trapped in headlights” because deers freeze (at first) when they see a human, or a car (headlights) then they bolt. The only time I’ve touched one was when a mother deer was “crying” (out loud) because her baby was trapped behind our yards fence. So we gently grabbed the baby deer & handed him over the fence to its mom. I wish deer were this friendly, then again that would make it easier for hunters to get them. 😕 Kangaroos & koalas are so cute. The coolest thing about kangaroos, which was mentioned here but only in passing, is that they're essentially born a fetus.

A baby kangaroo is born, like the man said, tiny. They look like baby rats. The mother licks a path to her pouch because the baby is completely blind. The joey crawls to the pouch (which can take a while) then gets inside and finds a nipple. It then physically attaches to the nipple - we're talking fusing flesh here. The baby then spends the next while essentially going through fetal development, and only leaves once it is a more recognisable kangaroo. Nuts!

I have no idea why this process evolved. Perhaps someone can tell me. It must somehow be superior to a longer pregnancy resulting in a more fully developed joey.

People here kept on complaining that it might be uncomfortable for the Kangaroo and I'm here, simply learning. As a biology student, we keep on learning things other people don't usually know. And for that, we need to examine and do what you call 'animal cruelty' or something that can make an animal 'uncomfortable.' In our ways, we learn through this kind of approach. If for example I didn't watch a video where a guy like him who is curious to see what a Kangaroo pouch looks like, then I might be the one to do it. But because he had already done it and I already saw it, I 'might' save the time to do it myself. You see, if we, including you, don't do this kind of things, we will not be too educated how to take care of these creatures. In other words, sacrifice one and save others.

And lastly, I don't see the guy being cruel or anything. And I don't see the Kangaroo being uncomfortable. Even though only the guy got the benefit on this approach, the Kangaroo, in my perspective, didn't receive any harm from that. So in conclusion, this video done nothing wrong.

This video is very informative and fun to watch! I have made a Kangaroo character and I had named him Joie, which is a little tidbit type of thing considering that baby Kangaroos are called joeys. I had also believed that a Kangaroo's pouch was much like the pocket on a pair of jeans and that it was across the belly. I thought this way because of Roo's mom from "Winnie The Pooh", as her pouch is across her belly and looks kind of like it would be similar to that of a jeans pocket. I now know that this is a fallacion, or false fact, that many people believe and/or have misconceptions about what a Kangaroo's pouch actually looks like when compared to the ones most, if not all of us, have seen in cartoons as children and/or with a child while either babysitting or just having a relaxing day with a younger family member. I thank you for uploading this video as it is quite informative as is and shows that a Kangaroo's pouch is not as large as we thought it was due to cartoons showing the pouches across the Kangaroo's belly. "i think he has a pouch" well if it's a HE then no he doesn't have a pouch. The "puch" is an external womb. the fetus after only a few days of development, eaves the mother's internal womb crawls up the stomach into the pouch where it attaches to a teat  (the nipples are inside the pouch) and continues to develop. When the fetus leaves the internal womb it's only a few inches long and barely looks like a kangaroo, it's in the pouch that the real development takes place. in fact whilst in the internal womb the mother's body can "suspend" development of the fetus, basically put it on pause.  it's called embryotic diapause and is basically having a baby on stand-by should something happen to the current baby,

A little closer to home:

Is a 'possum pouch similar to a kangaroo pouch? You won't even need to hop in a plane to find out. In fact, you probably won't need to leave your back yard.

re: prehensile tongue

I swear that our goats have prehensile lips.

We put them into a pen that was overgrown with wild raspberry bushes. They, of course, proceeded to devour the vegetation.

Of course, they started with the easy stuff. They are OK with grass, but find sumac to be really tasty. Then, they started to eat the raspberry leaves.

They started by nibbling the leaves from around the central spine. They were able to nibble away the leaf, leaving the central spine in place.

After they ate all of the available leaves, they started going for the tougher parts, like the spine that they had earlier rejected, and the ends of the stalks.

I don't know how they managed to eat the main stalks without impaling their mouth parts on the pickers, but they did.

Goats are amazing critters. They're pretty smart for herbivores, and are as personable as cats and dogs. They're also sneaky, and quite adept at getting out of their pens.

The way to test a goat pen is to throw water at it. If the water gets through the fence, the goat will, too.

OK, so that's a slight exaggeration.

Slight.

Don't know if anyone has picked up on this already, but the zoo keeper tells Destin that sultanas are raisins, this is technically incorrect as Raisins are dried white grapes whereas sultanas are dried white seedless grapes, usually the Thompson seedless variety. Sultanas tend to be paler in colour, bigger and slightly juicier than raisins. For info, there is also the currant which is a dried black Corinth (or Zante) grape...

This information is quite important in baking!

Point of fact: one of the features that differentiates lagomorphs (like rabbits and pikas) from rodents is that their testicles are in front of their penises, so it isn't just kangaroos.  


Another fun fact is that in males the structure that would be the pouch on a female grows downward and serves to protect the testicles, as disputes between males involve a lot of kicking , and you saw those claws they have. (I was once really curious about whether male kangaroos had nipples since they don't have pouches [they do] and learned all sorts of fun facts along the way.)

Also fun: A female kangaroo can hold two joeys in her pouch at a time and will produce two different kinds of milk to suit their developmental needs.

You usually do a great job on your videos, but this one really bothered me. I know lots of kids watch--and love--your videos. It can be very dangerous to approach, and especially touch wild animals, even in a controlled environment. Hundreds of people are injured every year thinking they can treat wild animals like they treat their pets. Recently, a little girl was killed by a deer when she withheld the potato chips she was feeding them. And three people have been gored in national parks this year when they took selfies with buffaloes. This video makes it seem like it's ok to approach and even touch wild animals as long as you pet them softly and talk sweetly to them. A dangerous message that could get a child or an adult maimed or killed.
